summary: Hey! I hope you're having a great day! Just wanted to ask you a couple of questions because I really like your metas. :) What do...
question: Hey! I hope you're having a great day! Just wanted to ask you a couple of questions because I really like your metas. :) What do you think is the significance of the Night's King and his queen? Do you really he was a Stark? Should it matter that he was a Stark?
answer:
Thanks, anon!

There are a few reasons for the Night’s King tale (though GRRM has said that he won’t be a returning character as he is in the show, so that isn’t one of them): one is for the general tone of the chapter it comes up in, another for some context surrounding the Others. I also think there are some vitally important hints in his story, though.

Here’s the passage for reference:

The gathering gloom put Bran in mind of another of Old Nan’s stories, the tale of Night’s King. He had been the thirteenth man to lead the Night’s Watch, she said; a warrior who knew no fear. “And that was the fault in him,” she would add, “for all men must know fear.” A woman was his downfall; a woman glimpsed from atop the Wall, with skin as white as the moon and eyes like blue stars. Fearing nothing, he chased her and caught her and loved her, though her skin was cold as ice, and when he gave his seed to her he gave his soul as well.    

He brought her back to the Nightfort and proclaimed her a queen and himself her king, and with strange sorceries he bound his Sworn Brothers to his will. For thirteen years they had ruled, Night’s King and his corpse queen, till finally the Stark of Winterfell and Joramun of the wildlings had joined to free the Watch from bondage. After his fall, when it was found he had been sacrificing to the Others, all records of Night’s King had been destroyed, his very name forbidden.

“Some say he was a Bolton,” Old Nan would always end. “Some say a Magnar out of Skagos, some say Umber, Flint, or Norrey. Some would have you think he was a Woodfoot, from them who ruled Bear Island before the ironmen came. He never was. He was a Stark, the brother of the man who brought him down.” She always pinched Bran on the nose then, he would never forget it. “He was a Stark of Winterfell, and who can say? Mayhaps his name was Brandon. Mayhaps he slept in this very bed in this very room.” (Bran IV, ASOS)

The Night’s King’s relevance is to Bran. The mention of fear and its necessity echoes back to the iconic exchange between Ned and Bran (“Can a man still be brave is he’s afraid?” “That is the only time a man can be brave.”) Old Nan takes the connection even further when she tells Bran that the Night’s King was a Stark, something especially significant when we-the-readers have been wired into the Starks being the series’ official good guys (or as close as ASOIAF gets).

Even if Old Nan is pulling this part out of thin air, the point she makes stands: everyone has good and evil inside of them, something Bran struggles with in ADWD as he continues to skinchange into Hodor despite the warnings. The magic Bran is learning is dangerous, and the moral implications of using it need to be kept in mind.

Which also, I think, echoes back to Bran’s suggested predecessor. The tale of the Night’s King is relevant not only as a warning to what Bran may be capable of, but also a purposeful parallel to what we’re discovering about Euron Greyjoy.

While Bran is in danger, walking the line between right and wrong, Euron’s ten miles over it. He has no qualms murdering, and even less about possessing people with skills he likely learned from the Three-Eyed Crow (but that’s another post). Based on Aeron’s TWOW excerpt chapter, Euron’s goal is nothing short of being the new Night’s King, a new, twisted sort of god. That, I would say, is the point of the story; it’s less about the figure of the past, and more about the two in the present, one being tempted by the darkness and the other having already embraced it.

Thanks for the question, anon, and I hope you have a great day as well!

blog.name: chatknowsnothing-yet
blog.title: Chat Knows Nothing (Yet)
blog.description:
Me, a normal French girl, with too many fantaisies for her own good. And time to analyze it. 
Also a fanfiction writer on my lost hours: https://archiveofourown.org/users/ChatKnowsNothing/pseuds/ChatKnowsNothing

body:
Err…

Wasn’t I supposed to post a chapter today? Well…

How about a song instead?

White as snow his fur was

But no true Wolf he was

With blood tears fate was settled

With fire all was meddled

He only heard the dragon’s roars

And its folly made his heart soar

O pray, O Mother

For his cry to reach its armor

.

Aerand Flowers. New singer in town. Now soon in your castle. Travels by feet, so to be expected one month after demand. At the moment at King Bran’s Court.

Would anyone be interested on hearing more of his songs? Or is he destined to choose between his tongue or his hands?

summary: I'm still pissed that Bran tells Theon, "you're a good man, thank you," in response to Theon protecting him from the Night King....
body: I’m still pissed that Bran tells Theon, “you’re a good man, thank you,” in response to Theon protecting him from the Night King. But Meera, who lost her fucking brother; and once Hodor died, singlehandedly brought Bran back to Winterfell got nothing. And Bran pretty much said you’re not useful anymore, bye. If that was a way for the writers to show that Bran had changed into the 3ER, then why did he even give a shit about saying something nice to Theon? Or saying thank you? Let him die still thinking he was a bad man, Bran shouldn’t care. I hate the writing so much. It’s fine for Bran to cast off, and be a dick to the one female character who had been protecting him and taking care of him during his entire journey beyond the wall. But Theon protects him for a single night, and that’s more deserving of appreciation apparently.

reblog.comment: I’m still pissed that Bran tells Theon, “you’re a good man, thank you,” in response to Theon protecting him from the Night King. But Meera, who lost her fucking brother; and once Hodor died, singlehandedly brought Bran back to Winterfell got nothing. And Bran pretty much said you’re not useful anymore, bye. If that was a way for the writers to show that Bran had changed into the 3ER, then why did he even give a shit about saying something nice to Theon? Or saying thank you? Let him die still thinking he was a bad man, Bran shouldn’t care. I hate the writing so much. It’s fine for Bran to cast off, and be a dick to the one female character who had been protecting him and taking care of him during his entire journey beyond the wall. But Theon protects him for a single night, and that’s more deserving of appreciation apparently.

If that was a way for the writers to show that Bran had changed into the 3ER, then why did he even give a shit about saying something nice to Theon? Or saying thank you? Let him die still thinking he was a bad man, Bran shouldn’t care. I hate the writing so much. It’s fine for Bran to cast off, and be a dick to the one female character who had been protecting him and taking care of him during his entire journey beyond the wall. But Theon protects him for a single night, and that’s more deserving of appreciation apparently.

blog.name: cometsweepandleonidsfly
blog.title: comets weep & leonids fly
blog.description:
Home is where one starts from. As we grow older
The world becomes stranger, the pattern more complicated
Of dead and living. Not the intense moment
Isolated, with no before and after,
But a lifetime burning in every moment
...
Love is most nearly itself
When here and now cease to matter.
--T.S. Eliot, "East Coker"

blog.name: ges-sa
blog.title: Gaming Entertainment Solutions
blog.description: Everything you need from Gaming, Movies, Comics, Cosplay and more...

summary:
New Post has been published on https://ges-sa.com/winter-is-coming-to-south-africa/ Winter is coming – to South Africa! 
 On...
caption:
New Post has been published on https://ges-sa.com/winter-is-coming-to-south-africa/

Winter is coming – to South Africa!

On Monday 23 and Tuesday 24 September Comic Con Africa will welcome one of this year’s most recognisable tv actors – Isaac Hempstead Wright, better known as Bran Stark from Game of Thrones. Reed Exhibitions Africa and ReedPOP announced the latest addition to the talent roll today with the news that the King of Kings Landing would be appearing for two days at Comic Con Africa 2019.

Viewers around the world were recently locked to their screens as Bran the Broken became the Lord of the 6 Kingdoms and protector of the realm in the season finale of Game of Thrones.

Isaac Hempstead Wright first came to our screens when he landed the coveted role of Bran Stark back in 2011. Since then he has been a pivotal character throughout the series, but few people could have foreseen him being made king, except for the three-eyed raven himself.

Game of Thrones set a massive ratings record for the season 8 finale, with over 19 million viewers. This record-breaking stat makes it the biggest telecast in HBO’s history and the most-watched scripted entertainment programme of 2019. According to the Workforce Institute at Kronos, it was estimated that over 10 million Americans would skip work the morning after the finale. With the Lord of the 6 Kingdoms visiting Comic Con Africa in September, we expect productivity in workplaces across the country to dip significantly.

Game of Thrones fans can expect to see Isaac on main stage panel discussions as well as photo and autograph signings. Details and pricing will be made public in due course.

Isaac can also be seen in John Crowley’s Closed Circuit for Working Title and The Awakening for StudioCanal.

Comic Con Africa will be held from 21 – 24 September 2019, at Gallagher Convention Centre in Johannesburg. Comic Con Africa is a multi-genre entertainment and comic convention that features comic books, games, arts, movies, pop culture elements and so much more.

For more information about Comic Con Africa 2019, please visit: https://www.comicconafrica.co.za/en.html

Isaac Hempstead Wright first came to our screens when he landed the coveted role of Bran Stark back in 2011. Since then he has been a pivotal character throughout the series, but few people could have foreseen him being made king, except for the three-eyed raven himself.

Game of Thrones set a massive ratings record for the season 8 finale, with over 19 million viewers. This record-breaking stat makes it the biggest telecast in HBO’s history and the most-watched scripted entertainment programme of 2019. According to the Workforce Institute at Kronos, it was estimated that over 10 million Americans would skip work the morning after the finale. With the Lord of the 6 Kingdoms visiting Comic Con Africa in September, we expect productivity in workplaces across the country to dip significantly.

Game of Thrones fans can expect to see Isaac on main stage panel discussions as well as photo and autograph signings. Details and pricing will be made public in due course.

Isaac can also be seen in John Crowley’s Closed Circuit for Working Title and The Awakening for StudioCanal.

Comic Con Africa will be held from 21 – 24 September 2019, at Gallagher Convention Centre in Johannesburg. Comic Con Africa is a multi-genre entertainment and comic convention that features comic books, games, arts, movies, pop culture elements and so much more.

For more information about Comic Con Africa 2019, please visit: https://www.comicconafrica.co.za/en.html

summary: It makes me sad Rickon was so young when he had to flee with Bran. I mean all of the surviving Stark children are Traumatized...
body: It makes me sad Rickon was so young when he had to flee with Bran. I mean all of the surviving Stark children are Traumatized and scarred with ruined childhoods but at least they have memories of the times when they were all alive and whole at Winterfell, with a mother and father who loved them and kept them safe. Rickon’s just gonna remember being scared and on the run all the time.

I mean all of the surviving Stark children are Traumatized and scarred with ruined childhoods but at least they have memories of the times when they were all alive and whole at Winterfell, with a mother and father who loved them and kept them safe. Rickon’s just gonna remember being scared and on the run all the time.

summary: I can’t believe it took me this long to realize that when Jon told Bran that he was a man now and Bran responded, “Almost” with...
body: I can’t believe it took me this long to realize that when Jon told Bran that he was a man now and Bran responded, “Almost” with a weird-ass smirk, he meant because he was becoming a king soon. Wow.

summary: You think Bran would put the man who molested his sister in the position of hand? Doesn't Tyrion still have allot of resentment...
question: You think Bran would put the man who molested his sister in the position of hand? Doesn't Tyrion still have allot of resentment of Sansa will that go away? And wouldn't Sansa still be married to him?
answer:
King Bran makes sense. Archmaester Sam and Master of Ships Davos make a lot of sense. Lord of Kingsguard Brienne makes so much sense.

But Hand of the King Tyrion doesn’t. I have made posts and reblogged other people’s posts and while I can see GRRM giving Tyrion this position which he once loved only for it to turn into ash in his mouth but Tyrion sexually assaulted Sansa, he murdered Shae because he was angry, he raped 2 women and he is a kinslayer (which I don’t mind in this case but it’s important in ASOIAF). I don’t get how giving a misogynistic and abusive man who is a serial rapist that much power is bittersweet. Like I don’t like people talking about Tyrion like he isn’t disabled but his show endgame is the same in the books and I’m stuck.

I see how it could happen but it feels very wrong. I love so many characters but in a series with so much sexual violence, ending it with Tyrion as one of the most powerful characters is beyond tasteless. It’s why my knee jerk reaction was, ‘he took someone else’s role,’ but I’m very much doubting that. We’ll see.
